definition: to have been through the hardships of life/to have been through the mill
to use up/to exhaust/to end/to finish/to the utmost/exhausted/finished/to the limit (of sth)/all/entirely

sentences.english: Look at these dreams so beaten and so battered.
sentences.chinese: 看看這些歷盡滄桑的夢想。

sentences.english: She has buffeted about from pillar to post for ten years.
We've been through a lot but we're still together. It must be fate.
sentences.chinese: 我們歷盡滄桑後仍然在一起，必定是命中註定的。

sentences.english: Go through vicissitudes of life , your needing to learn to ignore over.
sentences.chinese: 歷盡滄桑，你要學會忽略過去。

sentences.english: Some of the greatest faith heroes have been people who had the most broken lives and unworthiness.
sentences.chinese: 最偉大的屬靈英雄往往是歷盡滄桑，不配神重用的人。

sentences.english: Chinese literature has a very long history and has witnessed some turbulent times.
sentences.chinese: 中華文學實可謂源遠流長，歷盡滄桑。

sentences.english: Many small communities along the coast have seen good times and bad.
sentences.chinese: 許多沿海岸的小鄉鎮都曾歷盡滄桑。

definition: lit. a dream of Nanke/fig. dreams of grandeur
to fight for fame, grab profit (idiom); scrambling for fame and wealth/only interested in personal gain
lit. to return the jade annulus to Zhao (idiom); fig. to return something intact to its rightful owner
lit. to dispel the clouds and see the sun (idiom); fig. to restore justice
interactions between heaven and mankind (Han Dynasty doctrine)
lit. one body two sides (idiom)/fig. a situation with two sides to it
the State of Qǐ in modern Qǐ county 杞縣|杞县, Henan (c. 1500-445 BC), a small vassal state of Shang and Western Zhou for most of its existence
the country ruined and the people starving (idiom)
